results.title: Andersonville
results.creator_credit: John Frankenheimer, David W. Rintels and Turner Pictures
results.brief_description: Andersonville was the notorious Confederate prison where Union soldiers were kept as prisoners of war. It is a place where men who once fought alongside each other now kill for the shirts off their backs. Sergeant McSpadden (Frederic Forrest) and Josiah Day (Jarrod Emick) lead a fearless band of men against the brutality of the most notorious prison of its time and the savagery of its inmates. Hunted like animals and tortured without mercy, they must trust in each other and be willing to sacrifice their own lives for the chance to escape. Frankenheimer creates a powerful portrayal of the struggle for freedom where the only law is the law of survival.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Frankenheimer, David W. Rintels and Turner Pictures

results.title: And what of the future?
results.creator_credit: David Allen, Robert qAlbury and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Investigates some of the social consequences of microelectronics in relation to employment, the work ethic, and the individual’s right to provacy as the amount of computerized information grows.

results.title: And they lived happily ever after
results.creator_credit: Anne Henderson, Irene Angelico, Kathleen Shannon, Len Chatwin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film takes a long, hard look at marriage and motherhood as expressed in the views of a group of young girls and married women. Their opinions cover a wide range. At regular intervals glossy advertisements extolling romance, weddings, babies, flash across the screen, in strong contrast to the words that are being spoken. The film ends on a sobering thought: the solution to dashed expectations could be as simple as growing up before marriage. Award: Dubuque.

results.title: And now the screaming starts!
results.creator_credit: Roy Baker, Milton Subotsky, Max J Rosenberg and Amicus Productions
results.brief_description: In this horror film, set in a haunted house in the late 18th century, Stephanie Beacham plays a young bride who is raped on her wedding night by a ghost who takes the form of a disembodied hand. When she tries to uncover the malevolant, dark secrets of her husband’s ancestry she is thwarted at every turn, and those who try to help her end up dead. Utterly terrorised, her mental health begins to fail and a psychic doctor (Peter Cushing) is employed to cure her. Despite the dated special effects, this British thriller still has vintage appeal, drawing on the themes of demonic possession and a family curse. Also known as “Fengriffen” and “Bride of Fengriffen”. Adapted from the novel by David Case.

results.title: And the band played on
results.creator_credit: Roger Spottiswoode, Sarah Pillsbury, Midge Sanford, Home Box Office and Odyssey
results.brief_description: Based on Randy Shilts best-selling book which was drawn from a true story. The film exposes how the inaction and in-fighting amongst Government officials, blood banks, the scientific community and the general public contributed to the spreading of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome and the general ignorance about the disease. The film will evoke anger and shock, but is ultimately moving. Starring Matthew Modine and an all-star cast of Alan Alda, Phil Collins, Richard Gere, Anjelica Huston, Steve Martin, Ian McKellen and Lily Tomlin.

results.title: And justice for all [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Norman Jewison, Patrick Palmer and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Al Pacino plays Arthur Kirkland, an attorney who experiences firsthand corruption of the establishment that he works for. Burdened with the memory of clients who’ve suffered heinously at the hands of inefficient bureaucracy, Kirkland starts to realise how systemic the depravity is among his colleagues. Whilst defending a repulsive judge (whom he loathes for personal reasons) on a rape and battery charge, Kirkland is forced to decide whether or not he will become another a cog in the amoral wheel of justice. For Pacino this role was one of several he played in unsettling dramas, produced in the 1970s, that addressed urban angst, endemic judicial venality and the demise of the American dream. Directed by prolific Canadian filmmaker Norman Jewison (Fiddler on the roof, Moonstruck, Rollerball, Iceman, Jesus Christ Superstar), whose films have at times addressed issues of racial injustice in America (In the heat of the night, A Soldiers story, The Hurricane). Conceived as a satire, the screenplay for the film was co-written by director Barry Levinson, who along with Valerie Curtin was nominated for an Academy Award.

results.title: Anastasia
results.creator_credit: Anatole Litvak, Buddy Adler and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The story is based on a factual account of the mystery that surrounded the Russian princess Anastasia, youngest daughter of Tzar Nicholas II, who along with her family was imprisoned and shot after the 1917 revolution.

constellations_other.name: The spectre of the Romanovs
constellations_other.description: The Romanov dynasty has become a symbol of opulence throughout popular culture. Their final costume ball is even referenced in the coronation mood boards for Tony McNamara's The Great. Let's look at their history on-screen.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Anatole Litvak, Buddy Adler and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.description: Classic film from the play by Marcelle Maurette, adapted by Guy Bolton and screenplay by Arthur Laurents. The story is based on a factual account of the mystery that surrounded the Russian princess Anastasia, youngest daughter of Tzar Nicholas II, who along with her family was imprisoned and shot after the 1917 revolution. Or was she shot? Did Anastasia in fact live on? The scene is Paris in 1928 during the time of Russian Easter. A destitute and suicidal woman suffering from amnesia who remarkably resembles Princess Anastasia (Ingrid Bergman) is rescued by exiled Russian General Bounine (Yul Brynner). The suave, but forceful General, conspires to pass this woman off as the long-lost daughter of the Tzar for the sole purpose of benefiting from the Princess’s ten million pound inheritance. But there are many who remain sceptical, not least of all the Russian Grand Duchess (Helen Hayes), grandmother of the real Anastasia. An intriguing plot played out superbly by Bergman and Brynner but also made all the more intriguing following Bergman’s own Hollywood comeback from exile in Europe after her affair with Italian director, Roberto Rossellini. (Awards: Academy Awards, 1957, Ingrid Bergman for Best Actress in a Leading Role; Golden Globes, 1957, Ingrid Bergman for Best Motion Picture Actress - Drama)
